titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Seneca Club of Kings County records 2016.042
titlestmt.author: Maggie Schreiner

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:17:49 +0000.

did.unittitle: Seneca Club of Kings County records

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Seneca Club of Kings County (Brooklyn, New York, N.Y.)

physdesc.extent: in ten manuscript boxes, nine shoe boxes, and three oversize flat boxes

did.abstract: The Seneca Club of Kings County was established in 1899 in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, and is the oldest Democratic club in Brooklyn. The Seneca Club provides a social setting for community leaders, elected representatives, and public officials to meet and discuss issues important to the community and neighborhood. The Club helps citizens with local problems, such as housing, job placement, and neighborhood conditions. This collection includes administrative and financial records, correspondence from local residents on personal and local issues, and ephemera from electoral campaigns and the Seneca Club's annual Dinner-Dance. This collection also includes photographs of Seneca Club events, members, affiliated organizations, and prominent politicians.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Steven D. Cohn, Gerald Esposito, Minerva Moises, Ramona Vergara, John Witkowski, and Marc Liebman, 2016.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Routine financial documentation and correspondence was removed from the collection, as were newspaper clippings and blank forms. Duplicate material, including a substantial quantity of duplicate sample ballots, were removed from the collection. Plaques were reviewed in consultation with the donor, and the majority were discarded.
Copies of New York Red Book: An Illustrated Legislative Manual of the State (from 1912, 1929, 1930 and 1943) were separated to the library collection.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Seneca Club of Kings County was established in 1899 with headquarters originally at 125 Division Ave and later at 93 Division Ave, in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn. The club was formed in the wake of 1898 vote to consolidate Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and the Bronx into New York City, which the Seneca Club founders opposed. The Seneca Club was led by prominent leaders such as Frank Kelly from 1944 to 1946, Joesph Sharkey from 1946 to 1962, Leonard Scholnick from 1962 to 1972, Abraham Gerges from 1972 to 1982, and Steven D. Cohn since 1982. It is the oldest Democratic club in Brooklyn.

The Seneca Club provides a social setting for community leaders, elected representatives, and public officials to meet and discuss issues important to the community and neighborhood. The Club helps citizens with local problems, including housing, job placement, and neighborhood conditions. The Seneca Club holds an annual dinner at Polonaise Terrace in the Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Seneca Club of Kings County records, 2016.042, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: All materials in this collection were unfoldered, and there was no apparent intellectual arrangement at the time of donation. Materials were physically grouped by subject, and paper materials were housed in archival folders and boxes. All folder titles were supplied by the archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection documents the internal organization of the the Seneca Club, through administrative and financial records, as well as the club's interactions with local residents. Correspondence from local residents addresses personal and local issues such as housing, immigration status, military service, and employment. Seneca Club's annual Dinner-Dance is documented through souvenir programs and other ephemera. Electoral campaigns are similarly represented through ephemera, a sample voting maching, and a ledger containing handwritten and published election results, clippings, and campaign advertisements. This collection also includes photographs of Seneca Club events, members, affiliated organizations, and prominent politicians.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright for material in this collection is held by the Seneca Club of Kings County.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Puerto Rican Oral History Project records (1976.001), Interview with Edna Rosado Oliveras
Alan Maisel and Bernard Catcher collection on Brooklyn politics (2016.001)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains internal administrative and financial records for the Seneca Club of Kings County. Financial records include leases and a mortgage for the Club headquarters at 93 Division Ave, tax documents, cash books, and expense ledgers. Administrative records include membership ledgers, Executive Committee meeting minutes and correspondence, and certificates and proclamations. Also included are ledgers from the War Effort and Entertainment committees.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material in this series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: Applications Ledger for Housing at Jonathan Williams Plaza
Seneca Club War Efforts Committee Members

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The majority of material in this series is comprised of correspondence from local residents to elected officials and Seneca Club representatives regarding local and personal matters. Elected officials often referred constituent correspondence to the Seneca Club, and conversely the Seneca Club lobbied elected representatives on behalf of neighborhood residents. There is a significant body of correspondence regarding employment opportunities, immigration status, and military service, including deferements and reassignments of active duty soldiers during the Vietnam War. There is also a significant group of correspondence with the New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) regarding the availability of apartments in new NYCHA developments. Other topics represented in constituent correspondence include crime and incarceration, federal benefits, education, and local development issues in Williamsburg and Greenpoint. The series also includes correspondence from Seneca Club leaders, and a small number of subject files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material in this series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Souvenir programs and other ephemera from the Seneca Club's annual Dinner-Dance comprise the majority of this series, with the bulk of programs dating from the Diamond Jubilee dinner in 1973 until the present. A number of earlier Seneca Club events are also represented in this series, as well as several programs from the Brooklyn Democrats Awards Dinner.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material in this series is arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: King County Democratic County Committee Awards Dinner
102nd Anniversary Annual Dinner and Dance RSVPs
105th Anniversary Annual Dinner and Dance RSVPs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains electoral campaign materials, including ephemera produced by candidates, as well as materials produced by the Sencea Club itself. Candidates that are particularly well-represented in this series include Abe Beame, Al Lownstein, George Swetnick, and Steve Cohn. This series also includes one ledger containing handwritten and published election results, clippings, and campaign advertisements from 1928 through 1966 concerning races for a variety of national, state, and local positions. Other materials included in the ledger are election appeals sent out by the Club with voting guidance, poll information, and candidate photographs with a suggestion to take these recommendations into the voting booth. The series also includes a sample voting machine.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material in this series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: Primary Day Electoral District Tally Sheets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes photographs of Seneca Club events and members, as well as photographs of affiliated organizations and prominent politicians. There are a number of unidentified photographs in this series. This series also contains six plaques presented to Seneca Club members.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material in this series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: Harold Cohn United Jewish Appeal Plaque
Jewish War Veterans of King County

Steve Cohn United Negro College Fund Plaque

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Membership cards were maintained at the Seneca Club offices, and were used by the organization's leadership to track members and their interactions with the Seneca Club. Membership cards include names, addresses, and dates and descritpions of individual assistance provided by the Seneca Club. The Seneca Club frequently provided neighborhood residents with assistance in housing, employment, immigration, military status, and more. This information was used to encourage voter turnout during election campaigns.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series has not been arranged by an archivist. There was no apparent intellectual arrangment of the membership cards at the time of donation.
